seat: Trinidad & Tobago (appeal to Judicial Committee of the Privy Council, UK)
institution: High Court & Court of Appeal of Trinidad & Tobago / Privy Council (UK)
law_governing_contract: Law of Trinidad & Tobago; contract incorporated FIDIC 1987 (4th Edition, reprinted 1992)
fidic_edition: FIDIC 1987 4th Edition (Red Book – Works of Civil Engineering Construction)
works: Oropune Gardens Phase II Housing Development (infrastructure works)

core_issues.desc: Whether contractor entitled to TT$11.7m additional claim for equipment cost escalation under Clause 70.1
Whether Dipcon complied with notice and record-keeping requirements; fallback to 53.4 (default assessment by Employer)
Whether UDeCOTT’s internal board approval was required before liability could crystallise
Effect of Dipcon’s acceptance of TT$18.8m ‘full and final settlement’ while reserving extra claim
Whether parties’ deviation from FIDIC certification/payment process created enforceable entitlement based on course of conduct

factual_triggers: 2003: Contract signed for TT$25.9m + VAT, incorporating FIDIC 1987
2009: Negotiations on final account; UDeCOTT letter 4 Aug 2009 records agreement to ~TT$18.6m subject to board approval
27 Jan 2010: UDeCOTT proposed TT$18.8m as full & final settlement including TT$3.5m for equipment escalation
8 Feb 2010: Dipcon accepted TT$18.8m but requested consideration of extra TT$11.2m claim
2010-2012: UDeCOTT officers re-assessed additional claim at TT$11.68m but never took to board
10 May 2012: Dipcon letter acknowledged board approval still required
2012: UDeCOTT denied liability; Dipcon sued for additional claim
2017: High Court (Rahim J) dismissed claim; found no binding agreement without board approval
2019-2022: Court of Appeal dismissed appeal; held reassessment was outside FIDIC, required board approval
errors_identified: Dipcon failed to comply with FIDIC Clause 53.1–53.3 notice/record procedure
Reassessment by UDeCOTT officers could not bind company absent board authority
Dipcon itself acknowledged board approval requirement in 2012 letter
No evidence of Engineer certification of Additional Claim under FIDIC
Acceptance of TT$18.8m settlement undercut later assertion of binding entitlement
outcome: Privy Council dismissed appeal. Held that Additional Claim never crystallised — UDeCOTT board approval was a necessary condition, not obtained. Clause 53.4 did not bypass need for board decision. No enforceable entitlement to TT$11.7m extra payment.
risk_lessons: Strict compliance with FIDIC Clause 53 claim procedures is essential; late or informal claims risk being unenforceable
Employer’s board approval may be a legal prerequisite in state-owned or statutory entities — contractors must secure formal approvals
‘Without prejudice’ settlements or conditional acceptance letters do not guarantee entitlement absent compliance with contract machinery
Reassessment by project officers cannot substitute for formal Engineer certification or board sanction
Parties’ course of dealing can influence interpretation, but cannot override statutory governance requirements
